metadata.title: Serum-dependent and independent regulation of PARP2

abstract.text: PARP2 belongs to a family of proteins involved in cell differentiation, DNA 15 damage repair, cellular energy expenditure, chromatin modeling and cell differentiation. 16

In addition to these overlapping functions with PARP1, PARP2 participates in 17 spermatogenesis, T-cell maturation, extraembryonic endoderm formation and 18 adipogenesis. The function(s) of PARP2 is far from complete, and the mechanism(s) by 19 which the gene and protein are regulated are unknown. In this study, we found that two 20 different mechanisms are used in vitro to regulate PARP2 levels. In the presence of serum, 21 PARP2 is degraded through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway, however, when serum is 22 removed, PARP2 is rapidly sequestered into an SDS-and urea-insoluble fraction. This 23 sequestration is relieved by serum in a dose-dependent manner, and again PARP2 is 24 detected by immunoblotting. Furthermore, and despite the presence of a putative serum 25 response element in the PARP2 gene, transcription is not affected by serum deprivation. 26
These observations that PARP2 is tightly regulated by distinct pathways highlights the 27 critical roles PARP2 plays under different physiological conditions. 28 29

body_text.text: , these studies confirm that PARP2 is not 68 entirely functionally redundant with PARP1. Furthermore, they underscore the importance 69 of PARP2 in maintaining a number of key cellular physiological processes. For these 70 reasons, we sought to investigate the mechanism by which PARP2 is regulated under 71 normal and stress-induced conditions. 72

To investigate how PARP2 is regulated, a survey of several cell lines showed robust 73 7 COS-7, MCF-7, HeLa, NIH3T3, MEF F20 and IMCD cells were maintained in 117 Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM)/F-12 or DMEM supplemented with 10% 118 FBS, 100 units/ml penicillin and 100 mg/ml streptomycin in 5% CO2 at 37ºC. Cells were 119 treated with different protease inhibitors at the concentration and duration as indicated in 120 the figures. Cells were subject to serum starvation or maintained in medium containing 121 different concentrations of sera where stated. Transfections were carried out using X-122 tremeGENE 9 transfection reagent as per manufacturer's recommendation. To test if the 123 loss of the PARP2 signal on blots under serum starvation conditions was due to 124 sequestration rather than degradation, MCF-7 cells were cultured to approximately 90% 125 confluence in complete medium (CM) and then this was removed and replaced with serum-126 free (SF) medium containing 50µgml -1 cycloheximide (CHX) to inhibit protein synthesis. 127

The cells were incubated for 7hr, and then the medium replaced with CM containing 128 50µgml -1 CHX. The cells were cultured for 1hr and then lysed in Laemmli sample buffer. PCR products were resolved on 141 1% agarose gels and images captured with a FluorChem IS-8900 Imager ( (Fig. 1) . 231

The loss of the PARP2 signal in cells cultured in SF medium was not due to cell 232 death as within one hour, when cultured in CM, these previously serum-starved COS-7 233 cells had reacquired a PARP2 signal (Fig. 1B) . Furthermore, signals were comparable to 234 those in cells that had been continually growing in CM. These results showing that PARP2 235 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

To address whether or not serum had an 237 effect on altering the activity of the PARP2 gene, and specifically the SRE in its promoter, 238 MCF-7 cells were cultured in CM or SF medium for 30 minutes and then total RNA was 239 extracted and used for cDNA synthesis. Endpoint and quantitative RT-PCR using PARP2 240 primers showed that PARP2 mRNA was available regardless of the treatment (Fig. 1C, D) . 241

However, immunoblot analysis showed PARP2 signals in cells cultured in CM, but not in 242 those that were cultured in SF medium (Fig. 1E) . Together these observations indicating that PARP2 expression was not affected by 251 serum deprivation brought into question the significance of the putative SRE. More 252 importantly, they strongly suggested that the loss of PARP2 signals could be the 253 consequence of the accelerated degradation of the protein itself or its sequestration to a 254 compartment resistant to Laemmli extraction buffer following serum starvation. To test the 255 latter, 2% SDS and 8M urea lysis buffers were used to lyse NIH3T3 cells cultured under 256 CM or SF conditions. Results show PARP2 signals were absent in both SF cells lysed in 257 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

Since results indicated that PARP2 might be a short-lived protein when cells were 262 cultured in SF medium, an in silico analysis was done to identify PEST sequences 263 (mobyle.pasteur.fr), which are responsible for the rapid turnover of many short-lived 264 proteins (Belizario et al. 2008). Although no putative sites were identified in PARP2, COS-265 7 cells were cultured in CM and protein turnover examined when translation was blocked 266 using cycloheximide (CHX). Cells were cultured in the presence of CHX (50µgml -1 ) for 1, 267 3, 5 and 7hr, and then processed for immunoblot analysis to detect PARP2 ( Fig. 2A) . 268

Contrary to the rapid disappearance seen in SF culture, PARP2 appeared stable over the 269 7hr period. Similar results were seen for PARP1 and ERK, which together would indicate 270 that the loss of the PARP2 signals was serum-dependent. 271

The loss of the 62kDa PARP2 signal in cells cultured in SF medium prompted us 272 to undertake a more detailed investigation on the relationship between serum treatment and 273 the levels of PARP2 (Fig. 2B ). COS-7 cells were cultured in SF medium or in medium 274 containing increasing amounts of serum. Immunoblot analysis showed a similar staining 275 pattern for full-length PARP1 and its C-terminal fragment, regardless of whether serum 276 was present or not (Fig. 2B ). In contrast, increasing the serum concentration from 0 to 10% 277 resulted in the significant increase in the appearance of PARP2 (P<0.05; Fig. 2B ). Together 278 these results showed that PARP2, but not PARP1, changes in cells in response to serum. 279 Furthermore, the evidence with that seen in figures 1C and 1D, would suggest that this 280 increase is at the protein level rather than due to increased gene activity. 281

Having determined that PARP2 was available as an SDS soluble protein and this 282 was dependent on the presence of serum, the next question was to address how fast the 283 PARP2 signal would decline when cells were deprived of serum. To determine this, COS-284 7 cells were cultured in CM for 24hr until 90% confluence, and then the medium was 285 removed and replaced with SF medium. Cell lysates were collected at 15, 30, 45 and 60 286 minutes and then processed for immunoblot analysis with the H-250 PARP antibody. 287

Results showed PARP1 levels were unaffected by the serum conditions, and comparable 288 signals were seen in all lanes (Fig. 2C ). In contrast, PARP2 signals were absent within 15 289 minutes after serum deprivation (Fig. 2C ). This finding suggested serum starvation 290 activated an efficient mechanism to reduce the PARP2 signal, which could be either 291 proteolytic degradation or sequestration to an insoluble fraction. inhibitors were comparable to those in cells cultured in CM. These results, together 303 with those seen in figure 1A , led us to dismiss the notion that the decline in PARP2 levels 304 in cells growing in SF medium was a caspase-dependent, apoptotic-related event. 305

Since the caspase inhibitors had no effect on preventing the disappearance of the 306 PARP2 signal when cells were deprived of serum, the next step was to broaden the search 307 for other proteases that might be involved in the process. MEF F20 (PARP1 +/+ ) cells were 308 selected for these studies since the Yucatan PARP2 antibody provided little to no consistent 309 signal with human PARP2 but is robust in detecting mouse PARP2 (data not shown). 310

Furthermore, comparable levels of PARP2 were observed between F20, COS-7 and MCF-311 7 cells (data not shown). F20 cells were cultured in CM until 90% confluence and then 312 pretreated with 250µM leupeptin (LEU), 30µM pepstatin A methyl ester (PME), 30µM 313 calpeptin (CAL), or 50µgml -1 α-2-macroglobulin (α2-M). After 5hr, the medium was 314 replaced with SF medium containing the corresponding protease inhibitor. To inactivate a 315 broad spectrum of endo-and exopeptidases, cells were treated with the 1x HALT Protease 316

Inhibitor Cocktail, which contains AEBSF-HCl, aprotinin, bestatin, E-64, leupeptin, 317 pepstatin A and EDTA. After a 15-minute incubation, cell lysates were collected and 318 processed for immunoblot analysis with the Yucatan PARP2 antibody. Results showed that 319 the inhibitors, either alone or in a cocktail (HALT), were not effective in preventing the 320 disappearance of the PARP2 signal (Fig. 3B ). This led us to conclude that under serum 321 deprivation, PARP2 levels were not affected by an amino, serine, cysteine, metallo-and 322 aspartic acid protease. body_text.section: PARP2 is sequestered to an insoluble fraction after serum deprivation 372

body_text.text: having excluded the involvement of many known protease types responsible for its absence 374 after serum withdrawal, we set out to examine if PARP2 was sequestered to an insoluble 375 compartment following serum deprivation. If PARP2 was degraded rather than being 376 sequestered after serum withdrawal, then it was expected that the signals would not 377 reappear, as indicated in figure 1B, after serum was added and protein synthesis inhibited 378 with CHX. 379
body_text.section: PARP2 is sequestered to an insoluble fraction after serum deprivation 372

body_text.text: Immunoblot analysis with a PARP2 antibody (Axxora) showed, as expected, the 380 62kDA PARP2 signal in cells cultured in CM (Fig. 6A , lane 1). The PARP2 signal was 381 lost when serum was removed and remained so in cells cultured in SF medium and treated 382 with CHX (Fig. 6A, lanes 2 and 3, respectively) . Similarly, CHX had no apparent effect on 383 PARP2 when cells were cultured in CM (Fig. 6A, lane 4) . However, when cells were 384 treated with CHX, and cultured under serum-free conditions, were transferred to CM 385 containing CHX, the PARP2 signal appeared (Fig. 6A, lane 5) . In fact, the signal strength 386 was almost identical to cells cultured without CHX (Fig. 6A, lane 6) . These results would 387 suggest serum starvation led to the sequestration of PARP2 to an SDS-(and urea) insoluble 388 compartment, which could recycle back to a soluble form when serum was present. To 389 further understand the capacity of this sequestration, we overexpressed GST-PARP2 in 390 MCF-7 cells cultured in CM or SF medium for 15, 30 and 60 minutes. Immunoblot analysis 391 of these lysates, using a GST antibody, showed that the GST-PARP2 signal was 392 comparable between the cells cultured in CM and SF medium (arrow, Fig. 6B ). Lower 393 molecular weight signals were also seen on blots (arrowheads, Fig. 6B ), and although not 394 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

Thus, the evidence would suggest that either the 396 sequestration capacity was limiting, or the GST tag conferred solubility to PARP2, either 397 way with most of the ectopically expressed PARP2 free in the SDS-soluble fraction. 398

body_text.text: Together, the results indicate that serum withdrawal does not lead to PARP2 degradation. The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/483289 doi: bioRxiv preprint factor and/or mitogen stimulation. To investigate this, we cultured different cell lines in 418 the presence or absence of serum and then assayed PARP2 levels. The loss of the PARP2 419 signal in cells cultured in SF medium (Fig. 1A) , and its return when serum was replaced 420 (Fig. 1B) supported the notion that the PARP2 gene was serum responsive. Given this on-421 off appearance at the protein level, and the presence of the putative SRE, we had expected 422 to see changes in PARP2 mRNA expression under the different culturing conditions. This, 423 however, was not the case and the presence of a PARP2 amplicon in cells cultured in the 424 SF medium indicated that the message was available (Fig. 1C) . Furthermore, the fact that 425 the quantitative-RT-PCR results showed no significant differences in expression in cells 426 cultured under the different conditions (Fig. 1D) indicated that the regulation of PARP2 in 427 cells deprived of serum was not due to the direct regulation of the gene, at least within the 428 time frame of our investigation. Thus, the presence of PARP2 mRNA under the SF 429 conditions did not seem to contribute to the fast return (within one hour) of the PARP2 430 signal after serum was added to cells incubated in CHX to block new protein synthesis (Fig.  431   6A) . Also, the reappearance of the PARP2 signal when serum was added was dose-432 dependent (Fig. 2B) and not reliant on increased transcription that was dependent on the 433 putative SRE in the PARP2 promoter (Fig. 1D) . These results implied that PARP2 under 434 serum-free conditions was either being rapidly degraded (Fig. 2C) proteases at the forefront of candidates responsible for the serum-dependent changes seen 442 with the different cell types (Fig. 1) . Unfortunately, our analysis using a caspase-specific 443 and a broad-spectrum caspase inhibitor (Fig. 3A ) as well as a proteolytic inhibitor cocktail 444 (Fig. 3B ) ruled out the possibility that caspases were responsible for the proteolysis. 445 Subsequent experiments were designed to explore the ability of serine, cysteine, metallo-446 and aspartic proteases to alter PARP2 levels (Fig. 3B) . As with the caspase inhibitors, those 447 routinely employed to prevent proteolysis did not have an effect on the PARP2 signals 448 when cells were cultured in serum-free conditions (Fig. 3B) . It is unlikely, however, 511 that the loss or sequestration of PARP2 is a mechanism to prepare it for autophagic 512 degradation since inhibiting lysosomal enzymes with leupeptin had no apparent effect (Fig.  513   3B ). Serum deprivation and the way cells cope, however, is indicative of a stress response, 514 and although our results suggest that PARP2 participates in these events, it does not explain 515 why the protein cannot be detected following urea denaturation (Fig. 1F) . Urea is often 516 used to recover proteins from inclusion bodies (Burgess 2009), but there is no single 517 method of solubilization for every protein (Singh et al. 2015) . 518

body_text.text: Given the shortcomings on being unable to find a sequestration mechanism noted 519 above, our data does indicate that PARP2 is degraded through the UPS in cells when serum 520 is present (Fig. 5B) (Fig. 5A) , where cells should have retained some of the PARP2 protein when they 543 were transferred to serum-free medium. 544
body_text.section: PARP2 is sequestered to an insoluble fraction after serum deprivation 372

body_text.text: In summary, PARP2 was shown to be a long-lived protein that is continually 545 degraded by the ubiquitin proteasome system in cells cultured in medium containing serum. 546
body_text.section: PARP2 is sequestered to an insoluble fraction after serum deprivation 372

body_text.text: However, in the case of a cell stress response when serum is removed, PARP2, through an 547 unknown mechanism, is no longer in a SDS or urea soluble form, and it is not known if 548 this is a prelude to apoptosis or to some other physiological requirement. Nevertheless, 549 alleviating this cellular stress by the addition of serum recycles PARP2 to a form, thereby 550 allowing it to resume its enzymatic role involved in the pARylation of target substrates. 551 All rights reserved. body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. . https://doi.org/10.1101/483289 doi: bioRxiv preprint Graphical Abstract Legend Fig. 1 . Schematic representation of PARP2 regulation under different growing conditions. PARP2 maintains genomic stability by recruiting DNA repair machinery to sites of DNA damage (1), and when not required is ubiquitinated and degraded by the proteasome (2). Under stress condition (3), such as serum-starvation, PARP2 is either degraded in a proteasome-independent manner (4) or packaged into a SDS/urea-insoluble fraction (5).

In addition, PARP2 contributes to the translocation of apoptosis-58 inducing factor (AIF) from the mitochondria to the nucleus during oxidative damage to 59 DNA (Li et al. 2010), and it can control cell death and autophagy linked to oxidative stress 60 (Wyrsch et al. 2012). PARP2, together with the PPARγ/RXR transcription machinery, is 61 also important in adipocyte differentiation (Bai et al. 2007), in the regulation of surfactant 62 protein B expression in pulmonary cells (Maeda et al. 2006), and for hematopoietic stem 63 cell survival under steady-state conditions and in response to radiation stress (Farres et al. 64 2013). However, the loss of PARP2 can increase apoptosis, contradicting a focal cerebral 65 ischemia report that showed a suppression of AIF in PARP2 -/-(Li et al. 2010). Despite 66 these discrepancies, owing to cell specificity and exemplified by the PARP2 depletion 67 results in several cell lines (Boudra et al. 2015)

Immunoblot analysis with the PARP H-250 antibody 220 revealed a prominent 116kDa band corresponding to PARP1 in all cell lines with the 221 exception of NIH3T3 cells (Fig. 1A). A band at 89kDa, corresponding to the C-terminal 222 fragment of PARP1 (Chaitanya et al. 2010) was detected in COS-7 cells and weakly in 223 MCF-7 cells. The appearance of these bands did not change significantly when cells were 224 cultured in CM or SF medium. The H-250 antibody also recognized a 62kDa band, 225 corresponding to PARP2, in all cells cultured in CM (Fig. 1A). This band, however, was 226 absent when COS-7 or MCF-7 cells were cultured in SF medium (Fig. 1A). ERK staining, 227 used as a loading control in this and other studies (Fernandez-Garcia et al. 2007; Rygiel et 228 al. 2008; Xu et al. 2012) showed that protein was present in all samples, with approximately 229 equal amounts assayed in the COS-7 and MCF-7 lanes under the different culturing 230 conditions

FIGREF4.text: 243To address whether the loss of PARP2 signal under SF conditions had physiological 244 effects on cells, we used F9 cells to test whether the loss of PARP2 affected their 245 differentiation potential. F9 cells cultured in CM and treated with RA upregulated the 246 expression of differentiation makers Gata6 and Hoxb1(Fig. S1). Interestingly, F9 cells 247 cultured under SF conditions and treated with RA showed significantly lower expression 248 of Gata6 and Hoxb1 when compared to controls (CM + RA), suggesting that loss of PARP2 249 signal through serum starvation attenuates RA-induced differentiation of F9 cells(Fig. S1). 250

Omitting the 338 ubiquitination enzymes served as a negative control (lane 1, Fig. 4B), indicating that 339 PARP2 could be ubiquitinated in vitro. To confirm the ubiquitination of PARP2, COS-7 340 cells were co-transfected with pBCGST-PARP2 and pMT123HA-ubiquitin plasmids, and 341 then cultured in CM. Cells transfected without pMT123HA-ubiquitin served as a negative 342 control. Cell lysates were collected, and GST pull down assays were performed prior to 343 immunoblot analysis with an anti-HA antibody. Results showed that ectopically expressed 344 mouse PARP2 was ubiquitinated (lane 1, Fig. 4C), and the amount of ubiquitin (smear) 345 accumulated following MG-132 treatment (lane 2, Fig. 4C). As expected, no HA-ubiquitin 346 signal was detected in cells transfected with pBCGST-PARP2 alone (lane 3, Fig. 4C). A 347

FIGREF7.text: degraded by the proteasome in the presence of serum 354The ubiquitination results, together with those showing that the proteasome 355 inhibitor MG-132 prevented ectopically expressed PARP2 from degrading, strongly 356 suggested that the UPS was the mechanism used to regulate endogenous PARP2 levels. 357Unexpectedly, however, results showed that MG-132 had no effect on preventing358 endogenous PARP2 from being detected under SDS-denaturing conditions in cells cultured 359 under SF conditions (Fig. 5A). As a comparison, immunoblot analysis showed COS-7 cells 360 cultured in CM and treated with MG-132 had consistent PARP2 signals (Fig. 5B). In fact, 361 the signals increased with increasing concentrations of MG-132, which was confirmed by 362 densitometric analysis showing the significant increase over levels in cells cultured in CM 363 alone. Although PARP1 was reported to be ubiquitinated and degraded in the proteasome 364 (Ame et al. 2009), we did not see any appreciable change after MG-132 treatment, which 365 mimicked that seen under SF conditions. Together this data would indicate that when cells 366 were cultured in CM, endogenous PARP2 is ubiquitinated and degraded in the proteasome. 367

FIGREF8.text: were first identified as being players in DNA repair (Gupte et al. 402 2017; Wei and Yu 2016), and this involves initiating their poly ADP-ribosylation 403 polymerase activity (Barzilai and Yamamoto 2004; Dantzer et al. 2006a; Huber et al. 2004). 404 In addition to this crucial role, PARP proteins serve other functions involved in, but not 405 limited to the regulation of gene activity, cell death, the immune system, cellular 406 metabolism and differentiation (Bai 2015; Vida et al. 2017). PARP2 is required for 407 initiating the differentiation of F9 cells into primitive extraembryonic endoderm (Quenet 408 et al. 2008), and our results showing Gata6 and Hoxb1 expression under serum-free 409 conditions (Fig. S1) would indicate that PARP1 was unable to act in a functionally 410 redundant manner (Quenet et al. 2008) and implicating PARP2 in differentiation. 411 Whatever the case, and given this diversity, the mechanism(s) to control the level 412 and activity of these enzymes must be tightly regulated. In the case of PARP1 and PARP2, 413 basal activities are low, while in response to DNA damage this changes rapidly (Bai and 414 Canto 2012; Krishnakumar and Kraus 2010; Langelier et al. 2014). At the level of the gene, 415 the presence of a putative serum response element (SRE) in the PARP2 promoter region 416 (Ame et al. 2001) suggested that transcriptional activity might be influenced by growth 417 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF9.text: 450 cell-cycle progression (Puchi et al. 2010) prompted us to block its activity to see what effect 451 it would have on endogenous PARP2 levels in serum-deprived cells. Leupeptin, an 452 inhibitor of endosomal trypsin-like serine and cysteine proteases (Simmons et al. 2005) 453 had no effect, which ruled out the involvement of cathepsin L. Details of the inhibitor 454 studies suggested that the disappearance of the PARP2 signal may not be the result of 455 proteolytic degradation, but instead and as noted above, due to the sequestration of the 456 protein to an insoluble form under serum-free conditions (Fig. 2B). 457 The detergent solubility of constituents within a cell is determined by the chemical 458 properties of the substrates as well as the detergents. Some cellular entities are naturally 459 resistant to extraction by detergents (Horigome et al. 2008; Takata et al. 2009) while other 460 proteins may be converted to detergent-soluble or insoluble forms following various 461 stimulations (Peters et al. 2012; Reis-Rodrigues et al. 2012). For instance, serum starvation 462 causes the translocation of dynein to a more detergent-soluble compartment in NRK cells, 463 growth hormone receptors occurs due to ligand-induced formation of cross-467 linked disulfide bonds (Goldsmith et al. 1997). These reports and our results led us to 468 investigate if serum deprivation caused an SDS solubility change in PARP2. Furthermore, 469 they raised the question of what in serum ameliorates the SDS solubility of PARP2? 470 Conversely, why does PARP2 become SDS insoluble when cells are serum-deprived and 471 what process initiates this sequestration or biochemical change? More importantly, what 472 physiological function does this regulation serve in cells, or does it even have biological 473 significance? Despite the similarities between PARP1 and PARP2, that the solubility in 474 SDS of the former did not change following serum deprivation would indicate that serum 475 withdrawal activated a PARP2-specific mechanism. 476 PARP1 regulation has been studied extensively and the protein can be found in 477 lamin-enriched or DNA-bound detergent-resistant fractions (Frouin et al. 2003; Vidakovic 478 et al. 2004). Furthermore, PARP1 changes its solubility in NP-40 detergent when modified 479 by sumoylation following heat shock (Martin et al. 2009). Several other proteins involved 480 in regulating DNA replication and repair, e.g. PCNA, P21, OGG1, XRCC1 and CAF-1 481 P150 are also found in DNA-bound detergent-resistant fractions (Amouroux et al. 2010; 482 Campalans et al. 2013; Frouin et al. 2003; Okano et al. 2003). Although PARP2 functions 483in DNA repair, this association with DNA would only enhance its resistance to some 484 nonionic detergents including Triton and NP-40, but not to anionic detergents like SDS. 485

FIGREF10.text: also localize to the cytosol in gonocytes, spermatogonia and spermatids 491 in mice (Gungor-Ordueri et al. 2014), and proteins are known to change their detergent 492 solubility when associated with either glycosylphosphosphatidyl inositol enriched 493 microdomains, the cytoskeleton or when posttranslationally modified (Brown and Rose 494 1992; Fujita et al. 2011; Ledesma et al. 1994; Paladino et al. 2002; Refolo et al. 1991; 495 Waelter et al. 2001). Moreover, under pathological conditions proteins can become SDS-496 insoluble, as in the mouse model of Alzheimer's disease where amyloid β protein (Aβ) 497 changes to SDS-insoluble forms of Aβ42 and Aβ40 (Kawarabayashi et al. 2001) or in 498 Huntington's disease where the mutated Huntingtin protein with its polyglutamine repeat 499 expansion is resistant to SDS extraction (Heiser et al. 2000; Scherzinger et al. 1999). These 500 conversions to SDS-insoluble forms are disease-dependent and the combinatory effects of 501 conformational changes and oligomerization and fibril formation that appear irreversible 502 in patients with specific neurodegenerative diseases (Cruz et al. 1997; Diaz-Hernandez et 503 al. 2005; Dolev and Michaelson 2004; Wong et al. 2008). The conversion of PARP2 504 between soluble and insoluble forms under different serum conditions that we observed 505 suggests the protein adopts a physiological conformation in either condition, linked to a 506 stress response. This is evident in nematodes and yeast where the accumulation of SDS-507 insoluble proteins in cells is indicative of aging (Peters et al. 2012; Reis-Rodrigues et al. 508 2012). FIGREF11.text: . PARP1, the structural and functional relative of PARP2 is 521 ubiquitinated and degraded through the 26S proteasome, and the ubiquitination site is 522 mapped to its N-terminal DNA-binding domain (Wang et al. 2008). Two E3 ubiquitin 523 ligases, Iduna and CHFR, ubiquitinate and target PARP1 for proteasomal degradation in a 524 poly-ADP-ribose (PAR)-dependent manner (Kang et al. 2011; Kashima et al. 2012; Liu et 525 al. 2013). Interestingly, Iduna binds and ubiquitinates a panel of DNA damage repair 526 proteins including PARP2 (Kang et al. 2011). It is not known, however, if CHFR 527 ubiquitinates PARP2, but it is recruited to DNA lesions through binding to the PAR moiety 528 of pARylated PARP1, and is the first E3 ligase engaged in protein ubiquitination at DNA 529 damage sites (Liu et al. 2013). When this occurs PARP1 dissociates from DNA lesions and 530 is subsequently degraded in the proteasome. This degradation prevents cells from ATP 531 deprivation due to persistent poly-ADP-ribosylation (pARylation) (Liu et al. 2013) that 532 Liu et al. 2013) is likely the result of other DNA-dependent PARPs, possibly PARP2. If 536 so and in response to DNA damage, the presence of autoPARylated PARP2 may be the 537 result of it binding through the PBZ domain in CHFR. As attractive as this sounds, as serum 538 removal would have initiated mechanisms for cell cycle arrest (Bertoli et al. 2013), it is 539 unlikely with our cell lines that PARP2 ubiquitination and degradation contributes to cell 540 cycle arrest, as noted for CHFR-mediated PARP1 (Kashima et al. 2012). Our rationale for 541 disputing the degradation of PARP2 under these conditions comes from the MG-132 542 studies

(A) Immunoblots of protein lysates 974 from HeLa, COS-7, MCF-7, NIH3T3, and IMCD cells cultured in CM and probed with the 975 H-250 PARP1/2 antibody to detect PARP1 (top panel) and PARP2 (middle panel), and 976 with an ERK antibody for a loading control. For the COS-7 and MCF-7 lines, cells were 977 cultured in CM until 90% confluent, and then the medium was replaced with SF medium 978 for 1 hour. (B) The loss of the PARP2 signal in COS-7 cells cultured in SF medium was 979 not due to cell death since adding medium containing serum (CM) (lane 2), allowed cells 980 to reacquire the PARP2 signal. MCF-7 cells were cultured in CM until 90% confluent and 981 then cultured for 30 minutes in either SF medium or maintained in CM. RNA was extracted 982 from each sample and (C) endpoint and (D) quantitative RT-PCR was done with human 983 PARP2 specific primers. The + lane had reverse transcriptase added to the first strand 984 reaction, and the -lane was the control for genomic contamination. Analysis from qRT-985 PCR data did not reveal any significant differences between cells cultured in CM compared 986 with those cultured for various times in the absence of serum. (E) Proteins collected from 987 MCF-7 cells cultured as in (C), were used for immunoblotting analysis with antibodies 988 against PARP1/2 and ERK. The reappearance of the PARP2 signal when serum was 989 replaced was indicative that the cells had not undergone apoptosis. (F) Proteins collected 990 from NIH3T3 cells cultured as in (C), were used for immunoblotting analysis with 991 antibodies against PARP1/2 and β-ACTIN. After 20hr, cells were washed 165 in PBS (phosphate buffered saline) and proteins harvested by lysing in 1x RIPA buffer 166 (50mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, 150mM NaCl, 1% NP-40, 0.5% Na-deoxycholate and 0.1% SDS) 167 supplemented with protease inhibitor cocktail on ice. Cell lysates were stored at -80ºC for 168 GST-pull down assays.
